column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Modern biodiversity management and restoration relies on data, increasingly collected by sensors and robots and processed by computers. By connecting Australia, Telstra also enables researchers, park rangers, conservation organizations and citizen scientists to carry out their essential work.

Direct (Scope 1) GHG emissions
column7: Telstra's scope 1 emissions in 2023 were 30.738 tCO2e.

column6: Energy indirect (Scope 2) GHG emissions
column7: Telstra's scope 2 emissions in 2023 were 879.869 tCO2e.

column6: Other indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions
column7: Telstra's scope 3 emissions in 2023 were 1.865.812 tCO2e.

column6: GHG emissions intensity
column7: Telstra emissions intensity was 42 tCO2e/PB in FY2023. Total Australia emissions (scope 1 & 2) included in emissions intensity is 887.190 tCO2e.

column6: Reduction of GHG emissions
column13: In FY23, Telstra incorporated Telstra's scope 1+2 absolute emissions reduction target into the performance measures for Telstra's Executive Variable Remuneration Plan (EVP), making it a component of senior executive short-term incentives under Telstra's remuneration structure. It recognizes the critical nature of this target to Telstra's success and each team member's role to achieve it.
column22: Emissions reduction target, Executive Variable Remuneration Plan, remuneration structure

column6: Emissions of ozone-depleting substances (ODS)
Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: E-waste is growing three times faster than general waste streams. As a leader in the telecommunications and technology sector, Telstra stepped up its environmental ambition to improve our use of resources, reduce waste going to landfills and create innovative solutions.

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Telstra is implementing circular economy principles to design product solutions to extend material circulation. It includes initiatives to prolong mobile device lifespans and responsibly recycle devices through the Telstra eCycle program, which collected 632,919 devices this year.

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Telstra partners with social enterprise PonyUp for Good to recover Telstra and Telstra client technology and uniforms for reuse or recycling. PonyUp then donates 50 per cent of its profits to SecondBite, Australia's largest fresh food charity.

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Telstra is excited to integrate recycled plastics into its Smart Modem 3, furthering its sustainability initiatives. The company reduced ancillary items, eliminated unnecessary plastics, shifted to black enclosures, and pioneered a proof of concept using plastics from end-of-life modems, demonstrating innovation and environmental commitment.

column6: Waste generated
column7: Telstra's total Waste generated was 8.473 tonnes.

column6: Waste diverted from disposal
column7: Telstra's Waste diverted from disposal was 64.26 tonnes.

column6: Waste directed to disposal
column7: Telstra's Waste directed to disposal was 64.26 tonnes.

Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Telstra is committed to decarbonizing its business and assisting customers and suppliers in the same endeavour, aligning with initiatives such as the United Nations Global Compact's Business Ambition for 1.5ÃÂ°C and the Paris Agreement. This commitment includes setting validated emissions reduction targets by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi).

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column7: Telstra hired 2.703 new employees in 2023, with a 12.7% employee turnover rate.\t

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
Parental leave
column13: Telstra's EAs offer industry-leading terms and conditions, including superannuation payment during unpaid parental leave, gender affirmation leave, and 20 days of paid leave for permanent employees affected by family and domestic violence. Furthermore, starting February 2023, Telstra extended these paid arrangements to its casual workforce and introduced discretionary paid leave for employees supporting family members experiencing such violence.

column6: Parental leave
column7: The total parental leave at Telstra is 1,579 employees.

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
column8: Appropriate notice with the following legal
column13: Telstra is committed to providing appropriate notice and following legal, industrial relations and consultation requirements, if any, within the countries implementing a change.

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: In FY23, we recorded the highest level of incident reporting on record, which we broadly view as positive. It reflects a robust health, safety and well-being culture where our people are highly aware of the importance of accurate and timely reporting and feel comfortable reporting incidents.
column22: Incident Reporting, Health and Safety Culture, Wellbeing

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Telstra's FY23 incident reporting reflects a significant improvement, with a notable decrease in incidents resulting in high-severity outcomes such as medical treatment or work restrictions. This positive trend is also evident in marginal reductions in Telstra's Total Recordable Injury Frequency Rate (TRIFR) and Lost Time Injury Frequency Rate (LTIFR), indicating that higher incident reporting did not lead to increased TRIFR and LTIFR, demonstrating Telstra's commitment to safety.

Average hours of training per year per employee
column7: Average hours of training per year per employee in Telstra FY23 were 6.47 for executive management, 14.52 for middle management, and 16.76 for operational staff.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Telstra invested $20 million in training and development in FY23, with an additional $3.5 million in our Future Ready program. Within the total investment of $23.5 million, over $6.9 million was invested in technology training and $6.2 million in leadership training.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Telstra has continued to invest in its employees by establishing new technical skill programs for Software Engineering, Data and Analytics, and Cyber Security, including skills assessments and Capstone projects. Telstra initiated virtual Cyber Security Malware and Software Engineering internships with Forage.
column22: Employees, Technical Skill Programs, Virtual Internships

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Telstra is committed to delivering in-person cultural learning for 1,500 employees by June 2025 to deepen their understanding of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures, histories, knowledge, and rights. This initiative and partnering with a First Nations training provider for workshops form part of Telstra's broader efforts to enhance cultural competency across the company.
column22: Cultural Learning, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures, First Nations training provider
